content: Pen a limerick about a mischievous cat in the style of Lewis Carroll.

In the quaint village of Toodle-um,
Lived a cat quite beyond the norm.
With a grin as wide as a Cheshire,
He'd play tricks on folks, great and small.

One day, he stole a top-hat of Mr. Plumm,
And perched it upon his feline cranium.
The villagers laughed and clapped their hands,
At the sight so absurd and grand.

But beware, for this cat was sly,
With a twist in every tail he'd ply.
He'd vanish in a puff of smoke,
Leaving only a grin, oh so broad and crooked.

So if you meet him in Toodle-um,
Beware of his tricks and his charm.
For this cat, oh so sly and smart,
Is a riddle wrapped in fur, and that's a fact!
